children.subject: I think I knew someone who tried to take both (was a transfer student and had done an internship so had the programming knowledge that 61a gives) but they still dropped 61a because of 61b's workload. I really wouldn't do it, OP, and if you're confident in your programming skills and want to get lower divs finished early I'd suggest you to look into one of those courses plus cs70 instead.
OP here. Thanks for the input; I've decided to just take 61A!

Have you programmed before? Ideally I havent heard anyone do this and it seems pretty daring to do it...because a lot of stuff that was taught in 61A is built-up upon in 61B...so you would need to take 61A before 61B.

history.content: As someone who did it, I think taking them concurrently requires prior programming knowledge particularly in Python and/or Java. The way I managed it was to allocate less time to 61A (including lecture, homework, and projects) and even then, it was still a bit of a struggle to handle all the assignments. What really helped me was getting 61A projects done as soon as they came out and also watching Prof. DeNero's pre-recorded lectures ahead of schedule to gain some buffer to have more time to dedicate to 61B work.

The way I managed it was to allocate much less time to 61A (including lecture, homework, and projects) and even then, it was still a bit of a struggle to handle all the assignments. What really helped me was getting 61A projects done as soon as they came out and also watching Prof. DeNero's pre-recorded lectures ahead of schedule to gain some buffer to have more time to dedicate to 61B work.

Has anyone taken 61A and 61B at the same time? I'd love to hear your thoughts on how you managed your time and just get some general advice. My third class would be an intro-level language class.

Thanks!
history.subject: 61A and 61B at the same time
